data.text:
Northern Cardinal (Cardinalis cardinalis):
Appearance: Male Northern Cardinals are vibrant red all over with a black mask around their face and a prominent crest. Females are primarily brown with warm reddish tinges on the wings, tail, and crest. They have red bills and a reddish crest. Both sexes have a short, thick bill.
Song: The Northern Cardinal has a loud, clear, and melodious song often described as "cheer, cheer, cheer" or "purty, purty, purty." They also make sharp "chip" calls.
data.label: Northern Cardinal

data.text:
Blue Jay (Cyanocitta cristata):
Appearance: Blue Jays have a distinctive blue crest, back, wings, and tail. Their face is white with a black necklace extending down the sides of their head and neck. Their underparts are grayish-white. They have a long tail and a stout, black bill.
Song: Blue Jays have a variety of calls, including a loud, harsh "jay-jay" call and a softer, almost bell-like "tool-ool" sound. They are also known to mimic the calls of hawks.
data.label: Blue Jay

data.text:
American Robin (Turdus migratorius):
Appearance: American Robins have a dark gray-brown back and wings, with a rich orange-red breast. They have white throats with black streaks and a white lower belly. Their head is dark with white crescent-shaped markings around the eyes. They have a yellow bill and long legs.
Song: The American Robin's song is a familiar, cheerful series of clear whistles, often described as "cheerily, cheer up, cheer up, cheerily, cheer up."
data.label: American Robin

data.text:
Downy Woodpecker (Dryobates pubescens):
Appearance: Downy Woodpeckers are small, black-and-white woodpeckers. They have a black upper back and wings with white spots, and white underparts. Males have a small red patch on the back of their head. They have a short, stout bill and a black stripe extending from the bill to the neck.
Song: Downy Woodpeckers do not sing songs but have a variety of calls. The most common is a sharp "pik" sound. They also make a descending whinny call and a soft, rolling rattle during the breeding season.
data.label: Downy Woodpecker

data.text:
American Goldfinch (Spinus tristis):
Appearance: Male American Goldfinches are bright yellow during the breeding season, with a black cap, wings, and tail. Females are duller yellow-brown with black wings and tail. In winter, both sexes appear more olive-brown. They have short, conical bills.
Song: The American Goldfinch's song is a lively, high-pitched series of twitters and warbles, often described as "po-ta-to-chip, po-ta-to-chip."
data.label: American Goldfinch

data.text:
Common Loon (Gavia immer):
Appearance: The Common Loon has a striking black-and-white checkered back, a black head, and a white neck with a black band. In summer, they have a greenish-black head and a distinctive red eye. In winter, their plumage is duller, with a grayish back and white underparts. They have a long, pointed bill and are large, swimming birds.
Song: The Common Loon is known for its haunting, eerie calls. Their iconic call is a loud, wailing "hoo-hoo-hoo" that can be heard over long distances. They also make yodeling calls and short hoots.
data.label: Common Loon

data.text:
Mourning Dove (Zenaida macroura):
Appearance: Mourning Doves have a slender body with a small head and a long, pointed tail. They are grayish-brown overall, with black spots on their wings and a pinkish hue on their breast. They have a black spot on the side of their neck and blue skin around their eyes.
Song: The Mourning Dove's call is a distinctive, mournful "coo-ah, coo, coo, coo" sound that gives the bird its name. The call is soft and drawn out.
data.label: Mourning Dove

data.text:
Ruby-throated Hummingbird (Archilochus colubris):
Appearance: The Ruby-throated Hummingbird is a tiny bird with a slender bill and a forked tail. Males have a bright red throat (gorget) that can appear black in low light. Their back is metallic green, and their underparts are grayish-white. Females lack the red throat and have white throats with dusky streaks.
Song: The Ruby-throated Hummingbird does not sing but makes high-pitched chirps and twitters. Their wings also make a humming sound during flight.
data.label: Ruby-throated Hummingbird

data.text:
Tufted Titmouse (Baeolophus bicolor):
Appearance: The Tufted Titmouse is a small, gray bird with a white underside, rusty flanks, and a distinctive gray crest. They have large, dark eyes, a short, stout bill, and pale legs.
Song: The Tufted Titmouse has a variety of calls, but their most recognizable song is a clear, whistled "peter-peter-peter" or "cheevy-cheevy-cheevy."
data.label: Tufted Titmouse

data.text:
Baltimore Oriole (Icterus galbula):
Appearance: The male Baltimore Oriole is a vibrant orange and black bird with a solid black head and upper back. They have a bright orange underside and a white wing bar. Females are less vibrant, with a yellowish-orange head and underparts and grayish wings with white wing bars. They have a pointed, silver-gray bill.
Song: The Baltimore Oriole's song is a series of rich, flutelike whistles that are often described as "hew-li, hew-li, hew-li, hew-li." They also make a series of harsh, chattering calls.
data.label: Baltimore Oriole

data.text:
Red-winged Blackbird (Agelaius phoeniceus):
Appearance: Male Red-winged Blackbirds are entirely black with striking red and yellow shoulder patches (epaulets). Females are brown and heavily streaked, with a whitish eyebrow and throat.
Song: Male Red-winged Blackbirds produce a distinctive "conk-la-ree" song, often while perched atop cattails or other vegetation.
data.label: Red-winged Blackbird

data.text:
Eastern Bluebird (Sialia sialis):
Appearance: Male Eastern Bluebirds have a bright blue back, head, and wings, with a rusty-red breast and white underparts. Females are duller, with more grayish-blue upperparts and a paler orange-brown breast.
Song: The Eastern Bluebird's song is a soft, warbling "chur-lee, chur-lee, chur-lee" phrase.
data.label: Eastern Bluebird

data.text:
Cedar Waxwing (Bombycilla cedrorum):
Appearance: Cedar Waxwings have a sleek, buff-brown body with a black mask, a crest, and a yellow-tipped tail. They have distinctive red, waxy tips on their secondary wing feathers.
Song: Cedar Waxwings have a high-pitched, thin, whistling call often described as "sree" or "zree."
data.label: Cedar Waxwing

data.text:
Northern Flicker (Colaptes auratus):
Appearance: Northern Flickers are large, brown woodpeckers with black-spotted plumage, a white rump, and a black bib. The undersides of their wings and tail are bright yellow in the eastern populations and red in the western ones.
Song: Northern Flickers have a loud, rolling "ki-ki-ki-ki-ki-ki-ki" call and a piercing "klee-yer" sound.
data.label: Northern Flicker

data.text:
Tree Swallow (Tachycineta bicolor):
Appearance: Tree Swallows have iridescent blue-green upperparts and pure white underparts. They have a slightly forked tail and long, pointed wings.
Song: Tree Swallows have a liquid, gurgling series of twitters and chirps.
data.label: Tree Swallow

data.text:
Black-capped Chickadee (Poecile atricapillus):
Appearance: Black-capped Chickadees have a black cap and bib, white cheeks, and a gray back, wings, and tail. Their underparts are whitish with buffy sides.
Song: The Black-capped Chickadee's song is a clear, whistled "fee-bee" or "hey, sweetie." They also make a characteristic "chick-a-dee-dee-dee" call.
data.label: Black-capped Chickadee

data.text:
White-breasted Nuthatch (Sitta carolinensis):
Appearance: White-breasted Nuthatches have a blue-gray back, a white face and underparts, and a black cap (in males; females have a grayish cap). They have a long, pointed bill and a short tail.
Song: White-breasted Nuthatches make a rapid, nasal "yank-yank-yank" call, often compared to a tiny toy horn.
data.label: White-breasted Nuthatch

data.text:
Indigo Bunting (Passerina cyanea):
Appearance: Male Indigo Buntings are entirely brilliant blue, with slightly darker wings and tail. Females are brown with faint streaking on the underparts and a hint of blue on the wings and tail.
Song: The Indigo Bunting's song is a series of high-pitched, sharp, clear notes, often described as "fire-fire, where-where, here-here, see-see, put-it-out, put-it-out."
data.label: Indigo Bunting

data.text:
Hermit Thrush (Catharus guttatus):
Appearance: Hermit Thrushes have a brown back, reddish tail, and white underparts with heavy black spots. They have a thin, white eye-ring and a slightly curved bill.
Song: The Hermit Thrush's song is a haunting, flutelike series of clear, descending notes, often described as "oh, holy holy, ah, purity purity eeh, sweetly sweetly."
data.label: Hermit Thrush

data.text:
Pileated Woodpecker (Dryocopus pileatus):
Appearance: The Pileated Woodpecker is a large, crow-sized woodpecker with a black body, white stripes on the face and neck, and a prominent red crest. Males have a red stripe on the cheek, while females have a black stripe.
Song: Pileated Woodpeckers make a loud, whinnying call that lasts several seconds, as well as shorter "wuk-wuk-wuk" calls. Their drumming is loud and resonant, often compared to the sound of a jackhammer.
data.label: Pileated Woodpecker
